text: it took me a really long time to make a
Spanish tortilla at home I would look at
these authentic recipes and they call
for something like two cups of olive oil
and I thought it's kind of a lot of oil
but then I made one and I realized it
was so worth it so you want to slice up
your potatoes and then you want to block
them dry I just rolled them up in a
towel this gets rid of some of the
excess moisture and it also gets rid of
some of the excess starch and I have
diced onion onion is essential it really
has a great flavor salt and pepper the
thing about a Spanish tortilla is that
it's so simple there aren't a lot of
ingredients so you're just really able
to taste the ones that you have and now
I'm gonna fry them up so this is where
the oil comes in so I want to cook the
potatoes covered with oil I'm gonna need
about a cup and a half you want to let
the oil get warm and then I'll add the
potatoes and the potatoes are going to
absorb some of that oil and they're just
gonna get this incredibly rich flavor
but we do pour off some of this at the
end so it's not like we're gonna eat the
entire cup and a half all the potatoes
should be in contact with some oil so
depending on how large your pan is you
may need to use a little bit more oil a
little bit less oil now I'm just gonna
let this cook until the potatoes are
soft it's gonna take about ten or
fifteen minutes I'm gonna leave it but
I'm not gonna go far away you know pokum
every once in a while you want the
potatoes to be really tender it's just
no resistance to the fork at all and now
I'm gonna drain them so you can see that
the onions aren't very very slightly
golden brown but they don't have any
dark brown on them which is what you
want you're not exactly frying you're
sort of poaching and olive oil and you
can reuse this oil I'm actually gonna
save a little bit of it and use it for a
little salad that I'm gonna serve on the
side and the oil is infused with the
flavors of onion and potatoes so it
tastes really good well now we need the
eggs didn't forget about those pepper so
you just want to whisk your eggs until
they're homogeneous keep the whisking to
a minimum
we want you onions come with us to
tortilla land just gonna heat up this
pan again so you want to just cook it
about halfway on the top of the stove
you know just stirring it around that
looks pretty good that's where I want it
I'm just gonna pop it right in the oven
now traditionally you would not make a
tortilla this way you would actually
flip it and brown the other side but
does anyone really want to do that I
don't do that and I think it tastes just
as good it only takes about five minutes
that is ready you want it to be solid
you don't want to see any liquid just
push down a little bit and it should be
firm I know I'm supposed to make this
look easy but this is actually I don't
know why I always get nervous at this
part ah didn't stick there we go
often when you get served a tortilla
you'll get a little bit of tomato sauce
to go with it but instead of doing it
that way I thought I'd make a little
tomato salad it's a bit fresher it's
wintertime so I have grape tomatoes
these are your best bet for winter
tomato fresh dishes this is called an
Italian frying pepper or a cubanelle
pepper and it's mild it's not spicy but
it's a little bit more delicate than a
bell pepper my tomatoes garlic scallions
and I'm gonna add back a little bit of
this olive oil that we cook the tortilla
and because it tastes good it tastes
oniony so this is the way I would serve
it for maybe a holiday brunch but if I
wanted to do this for a cocktail party I
would cut it up into wedges or little
squares first and then I'd either serve
the salad on the side or just a little
bit on tap of each one and that's the
great thing about tortilla you can serve
it warm you could serve it at room
temperature it's a very adaptable thing
